title: What Technology may an older person not have? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can only speak for myself. Technology information and equipment are missing here. It’s difficult when the world “requires” you to communicate via waves yet doesn’t provide the money to do so. Theirs are silly demands. Years ago I was able to put up 5 websites and 4 were removed because of Yahoo and Bravanet changes. I still have one but can’t update it. I was in messenger and that went away, and all the work I did on Yahoo profile pages with regard to where to find jobs went away too. It was fun being able to talk with some people overseas for a few years. When u-tube came into being none of my computers were able to see that, then one of my computers could no longer reach the internet because of Microsoft’s change in programs. There have been so many changes by the makers of computers, laptops and desktops that they are about to knock out the poor and seniors. Just trying to solve a problem thru calling support is like talking to the wall and always has been. Techs expect that everyone has a cellphone and that’s not the case. Now we’re being blocked by upgrades of the software and hardware techs. I’ve also found techs don’t or won’t do what I need them to do with regard to a desktop computer. Oh sure they toot their horn as to how great they are and that they have a satellite phone (who cares?) and their knowledge is up-to-date, and then they pat you on the head and say yes they still love working with Windows XP and just give them a call and they’ll fix any problem. Then just try to call them when the need arises and you get a thousand excuses, a snotty tech, and you hear the word “no” a lot. What good are they? See technology has not been easy for us. From the start we couldn’t even get trainers, we had to learn what we know from trial and error. And to date we use what we learned to use, certainly not using everything on the internet (we’re limited). I don’t like it when banks, retail, news places try to force us to use online. I keep wondering what young people and businesses are going to do “IF” we ever had to do without. I remember during the last hurricane hit where I live and we were without phone, without tv, without cellphone contact, without internet service. I had to drive my car to the apartment complex office to see people, and to find someone to ask what’s going on. While internet is nice, people need to learn to live without it.

I went to college in the mid-90s. PCs were really starting to come into their own at that time. The Internet was getting started, and the new Pentium II computers were hot-rods compared to the older AT/XT computers, or the 386s and 486s. CD Rom drives were starting to become widespread. And by this time, every computer had a mouse. One of the students I tutored was a part-time student who worked in a computer store. He had received complaints that the cup-holder on the computer broke and wouldn’t retract. Yep—the CD Rom drive. One old fellow thought it was to hold his Big Gulp. Another old lady complained that the foot pedal wouldn’t work. What???? She thought the mouse was a foot pedal, like her old Singer sewing machine. I remember around this time, my uncle and cousin were trying to push a PC on to my grandmother. They insisted she to had have one. It was the rage—right? Who could possibly not have a computer by 1995? The answer of course, was my grandmother. Well, they didn’t listen to her, and bought her one that Christmas. My grandmother, who never shied from speaking her mind, declared that the only thing good it would do for her was to serve as a dust collector. She was right, they were wrong, and it sat in the corner of her den and I don’t think she ever so much as turned it on. OP and every one else—are you paying attention? Okay. Read this very carefully: Do not try to foist the latest technology on to your 75 year old grandparents when they don’t ask for it and don’t want it.
